Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Multidimensional Signal Processing With Box Splines

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
This research develops a novel framework for interpolation and approximation of multivariate data.
The research introduces a method for construction of non-separable multivariate splines that are geometrically
tailored for general sampling lattices with emphasis on sphere packing and covering lattices
in multidimensions. These multivariate splines lead to the design of multidimensional signal processing
tools, that have proven degree of continuity and approximation order for sampling lattices.
The splines under investigation, called Voronoi splines, are B-spline-like elements that inherit the
geometry of any sampling lattice from its Voronoi cell and form basis for reconstruction. Furthermore,
the relationship of the proposed splines with the well-known multivariate box splines are investigated
and used for evaluation purposes. Compared to other polyhedral splines, Voronoi splines form shiftinvariant
spaces for approximation. This property makes them uniquely suitable for multidimensional
signal processing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hexagonal, Body Centered Cubic (BCC) and Face Centered Cubic (FCC) lattices, together with their higher dimensional counterparts are known for efficient sampling in multidimensions. Their sampling theoretic advantages make them attractive for many multidimensional signal processing applications. This project developed a set of signal processing tools for processing data sampled on these optimal lattices. These tools enable practical applications in image and signal processing to benefit from the theoretical advantages of these optimal lattices.

Specifically, we developed a family of splines, called Voronoi splines, that are tailored to the geometry of the lattice and provide  (non-separable) interpolation and other filtering methods -- of any desired order -- on the lattice. While we demonstrated this spline construction for all 2-D and 3-D lattices, we also established its generalizations to higher dimensions. Moreover, we developed a geometric approach for explicit derivation of lattice sinc functions -- generalization of the univariate sinc function to multidimensional lattices. These sinc functions are useful for building Lanczos filters on multidimensional lattices.

Using the signal processing tools, developed in this project, we demonstrated the practical advantages of employing optimal lattices for sampling 3-D functions. Moreover, we demonstrated the superiority of these lattices for reconstruction of irregularly sampled data. While the stability of these lattices to spatial noise has been demonstrated in statistical mechanics, we provided concrete evidence that their stability -- rooted in lattice symmetries -- is also beneficial to irregular sampling problems.
